<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 847, 728, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 667, 89]]<|/det|> Which list contains two scalar quantities and two vector quantities? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 403, 117]]<|/det|> distance, speed, time, velocity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 134, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 403, 144]]<|/det|> force, velocity, distance, mass <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 152, 482, 170]]<|/det|> mass, energy, temperature, momentum <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 134, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 178, 485, 196]]<|/det|> weight, acceleration, momentum, speed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 99, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 544, 241]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the speed–time graph for a car. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 248, 665, 388]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 678, 420]]<|/det|> Which row describes the motion of the car at point X and at point Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 744, 562]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The drag force on a car increases with speed. At \(20 \text{m / s}\), the total drag force is \(400 \text{N}\). The mass of the car is \(1200 \text{kg}\) and the driving force is constant at \(700 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 702, 135]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the acceleration of the car at \(20 \text{m / s}\) is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 144, 133, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 672, 163]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is \(0.25 \text{m / s}^2\) but will decrease as time passes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 170, 133, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 665, 189]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is \(0.25 \text{m / s}^2\) but will increase as time passes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 197, 133, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 196, 672, 215]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is \(0.58 \text{m / s}^2\) but will decrease as time passes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 133, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 222, 665, 240]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is \(0.58 \text{m / s}^2\) but will increase as time passes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 96, 287]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 589, 287]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 400, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 443, 346]]<|/det|>
The density of the water is \(1000 \text{kg / m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 465, 376]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 134, 403]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 198, 403]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 384, 567, 403]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 920, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 475, 885, 494]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 742, 91]]<|/det|>
An oil tank has a base of area \(2.5 \text{m}^2\) and is filled with oil to a depth of \(1.2 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 405, 120]]<|/det|>
The density of the oil is \(800 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 641, 150]]<|/det|>
What is the force exerted on the base of the tank due to the oil?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 160, 203, 179]]<|/det|>
940N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 160, 381, 179]]<|/det|>

<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 205, 920, 240]]<|/det|>
A sample of gas is trapped in a rigid container. As the temperature of the gas is increased, the pressure increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 384, 268]]<|/det|>
Which statement is **not** correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 279, 134, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 279, 544, 297]]<|/det|>
The gas molecules have greater kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 306, 134, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 305, 608, 324]]<|/det|>
The gas molecules hit the walls of the container harder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 134, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 332, 685, 351]]<|/det|>
The gas molecules hit the walls of the container more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 358, 134, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 472, 377]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 401, 106, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 604, 420]]<|/det|>
What happens when the temperature of a liquid increases?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 429, 133, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 429, 668, 448]]<|/det|>
The mass of the liquid increases, making the liquid less dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 133, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 456, 678, 475]]<|/det|>
The mass of the liquid increases, making the liquid more dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 131, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 685, 502]]<|/det|>
The volume of the liquid increases, making the liquid less dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 133, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 509, 695, 528]]<|/det|>
The volume of the liquid increases, making the liquid more dense.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 552, 107, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 552, 710, 571]]<|/det|>
A bar of metal, which is a good thermal conductor, is heated at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 581, 688, 600]]<|/det|>
What is the main method of transfer of thermal energy along the bar?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 611, 133, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 611, 280, 628]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 636, 133, 655]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 636, 534, 655]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 663, 133, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 663, 324, 682]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 133, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 437, 708]]<|/det|>
vibration of atoms of the metal bar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 445, 88]]<|/det|> A transverse wave moves along a rope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 658, 120]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the position of the rope at one particular time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 129, 801, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 247, 554, 266]]<|/det|> Which two labelled points are one wavelength apart? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 276, 134, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 276, 178, 294]]<|/det|> W and X <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 276, 300, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 276, 393, 294]]<|/det|> W and Z <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 276, 485, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[488, 276, 556, 294]]<|/det|> X and Z <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 276, 636, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 276, 725, 294]]<|/det|> Y and Z <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 322, 106, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 920, 355]]<|/det|> Light in transparent plastic meets a boundary with air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 808, 89]]<|/det|> A wire is moved across a magnetic field. This causes an induced current in the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 803, 119]]<|/det|> The induced current interacts with the magnetic field to produce a force on the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 373, 149]]<|/det|> In which direction is this force? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 179]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 160, 391, 178]]<|/det|> in the direction of the current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 186, 133, 204]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 186, 479, 203]]<|/det|> in the direction of movement of the wire <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 133, 231]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 212, 465, 230]]<|/det|> in the opposite direction to the current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 133, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 237, 584, 255]]<|/det|> in the opposite direction to the movement of the wire <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 284, 106, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 282, 826, 301]]<|/det|> A \(100\%\) efficient step-down transformer has primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) and primary current \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 831, 332]]<|/det|> Which row compares the secondary voltage with \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) and the secondary current with \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\) ? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 344, 534, 473]]<|/det|>
secondary voltagesecondary current
Agreater than \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\)greater than \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\)
Bgreater than \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\)less than \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\)
Cless than \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\)greater than \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\)
Dless than \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\)less than \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 501, 106, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 501, 831, 520]]<|/det|> The scattering of \(\alpha\)-particles by a thin metal foil supports the nuclear model of an atom. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 532, 510, 551]]<|/det|> Why are \(\alpha\)-particles used rather than neutrons? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 561, 133, 580]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 561, 482, 580]]<|/det|> because they always travel more slowly <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 133, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 588, 364, 606]]<|/det|> because they are heavier <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 133, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 615, 448, 632]]<|/det|> because they are larger in diameter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 133, 658]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 640, 455, 658]]<|/det|> because they have a positive charge <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 682, 106, 701]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 549, 701]]<|/det|> An iron nuclide is represented by the symbol shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 712, 532, 740]]<|/det|> \[56 \frac{56}{26} \text{Fe}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 663, 775]]<|/det|> Which statements about a nucleus of this iron nuclide are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 787, 210, 806]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 787, 510, 806]]<|/det|> The nucleus contains 56 neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 814, 448, 833]]<|/det|> The nucleon number is 30. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 841, 433, 858]]<|/det|> The proton number is 26. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 870, 134, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 870, 170, 887]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 870, 298, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 870, 384, 887]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 870, 475, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 870, 551, 887]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 870, 635, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 870, 660, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[663, 870, 707, 887]]<|/det|> only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A sample of a radioactive isotope has an initial rate of emission of 128 counts per minute and a half-life of 4 days. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 734, 135]]<|/det|> How long will it take for the rate of emission to fall to 32 counts per minute? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 134, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 145, 210, 163]]<|/det|> 2 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 145, 300, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 145, 378, 163]]<|/det|> 4 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 144, 467, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 144, 495, 163]]<|/det|> 8 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 144, 636, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 144, 723, 163]]<|/det|> 12 days <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 190, 107, 208]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 190, 920, 223]]<|/det|> Several scientists are working in a laboratory. The scientists are experimenting with sources which emit ionising radiation. Each scientist is given a list of safety rules. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 235, 361, 253]]<|/det|> Three of the rules are shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 265, 212, 282]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 265, 574, 282]]<|/det|> Keep at least 2 m away from other people. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 291, 205, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 291, 695, 310]]<|/det|> Do not stay longer than 4 hours per day in the laboratory. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 317, 205, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 317, 504, 336]]<|/det|> Stay behind the lead-lined screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 744, 365]]<|/det|> Which safety rules are for protection against the effects of ionising radiation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 375, 133, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 375, 240, 393]]<|/det|> 1, 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 375, 300, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 375, 440, 393]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 375, 485, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 375, 536, 393]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[565, 375, 585, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[595, 375, 616, 393]]<|/det|> 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 375, 757, 393]]<|/det|> and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 419, 106, 439]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 419, 860, 439]]<|/det|> Which data is needed to calculate the average orbital speed of a satellite around a planet? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 871, 612]]<|/det|>
the distance of the satellite from the centre of the planetthe radius of the planetthe period of rotation of the planetthe time for the satellite to orbit the planet once

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 149, 642]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 215, 667]]<|/det|> \(\checkmark\) = needed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 677, 245, 694]]<|/det|> \(\boldsymbol {x}\) = not needed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 721, 106, 740]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 721, 865, 740]]<|/det|> Approximately how long does it take for the Moon to make one complete orbit of the Earth? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 134, 768]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 750, 228, 768]]<|/det|> 24 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 134, 795]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 777, 223, 795]]<|/det|> 1 month <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 803, 133, 821]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 803, 230, 821]]<|/det|> 1 season <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 829, 133, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 829, 208, 848]]<|/det|> 1 year

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 675, 89]]<|/det|> The energy generated in stable stars comes from nuclear reactions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 463, 120]]<|/det|> Which type of reaction occurs in the Sun? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 544, 147]]<|/det|> Helium nuclei break up to give hydrogen nuclei. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 131, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 578, 175]]<|/det|> Helium nuclei join together to form hydrogen nuclei. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 544, 201]]<|/det|> Hydrogen nuclei break up to give helium nuclei. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 578, 227]]<|/det|> Hydrogen nuclei join together to form helium nuclei. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 106, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 494, 272]]<|/det|> Two quantities define the Hubble constant \(H_0\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 284, 742, 301]]<|/det|> ● the speed at which the galaxy is moving away from the Earth \(v\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 310, 578, 327]]<|/det|> ● the distance of the galaxy from the Earth \(d\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 784, 357]]<|/det|> What is the relationship between \(v\) and \(d\) and what is the current estimate for \(H_0\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 368, 636, 522]]<|/det|>
relationshipcurrent estimate for \(H_0\)
A\(v\) is proportional to \(d\)\(2.2 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\)
B\(v\) is proportional to \(\frac{1}{d}\)\(2.2 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\)
C\(v\) is proportional to \(d\)\(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
D\(v\) is proportional to \(\frac{1}{d}\)\(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
